Littéralement Overwatch 1 avec moins de contenu et plus de micro-transactions, en bref, un jeu toujours aussi inintéressant, ennuyeux, qui plaira qu'au gens sans goût et qui reflète au final bien l'industrie cancérigène du jeu vidéo, autant jouer à TF2.

I used to play first Overwatch for YEARS since the release to 2019. I stopped playing at December 2019. The reason? Lack of new stuff, even if Sigma appeared. And here we are, it's 2023 and actual new stuff make the game WORSE.
I have no idea how Blizzard could mess up the game which wall all over the internet, everyone talked about it and played it.

So what I used to like in first OW... Lootboxes. For real, and now I seriously miss them. During events I knew what I can get and with some luck I could get those stuff without spending money. If event was near the end and I still didn't have the legendary skin, I was buying some boxes time to time. Of course I didn't have to tho, that was my decision.
Here, in Overwatch 2, battle pass tells you "Spend your money on those goodies, or grind like crazy to get those skins OR EVEN UNLOCK THE CHARACTER"... Rly? I've never felt like I have to spend real cash to unlock character earlier and if I will decided to grind and miss it then blizzard showes me middle finger. I hate grind, I have my own life, responsibilities, and I don't have enough time to avoid Blizzard's greed other way than spending money.

In OW 1 I didn't feel like I literally have to work for those stuff. And the game could survive at its previous form only if Blizzard would decide to change neccesary things and stop changing things which no one needed. And SUPPORT THE GAME. Isn't it funny how Ubisoft still holds Siege in form which it used to be with improvements since 2015, but Blizzard failed? Check out old Battlefield titles, which won't even change now but people keep playing and love those games. Don't change what works! That's simple.

I truly miss first Overwatch, and wish I could play it, feel the excitement seeing gold effect jumping out of the box and hoping it's the skin I wish for. Back then I wouldn't think I will be missing lootboxes so much.

[h1] Harshly broken and little fun to be had. [/h1]

It's hard to pin down all the problems with this game in one comment, but here are the ones that stand out most to me:

With every update a hero becomes meta and the rest of the game suffers. Currently, the meta is Roadhog (who already made the game unplayable without other heroes' deficits). Between healing through outstanding incoming damage and being able to top literal support heroes in healing, there really isn't a better pick. This is a shame considering we have 34 other heroes that can't do anythingin comparison. Like I said, this isn't just limited to Roadhog, this is whoever the devs decide to make a god so they can convince people to play their dying game.

Free to Play! This would have been a great renovation if anyone had asked for it. Other players arguing for this addition seem to forget that Overwatch was already complacent with micro-transactions. I can see no benefit to making this game free to play and adding MORE micro-transactions...maybe because there is no benefit aside from a larger salary. 

Competitive...a fundamental part of the game
In my opinion, the very idea of Blizzard lowering my SR to "encourage" gameplay is enough to make sure I never play this game again. The "slight decay" took me from Plat 1 to Silver 5. There's a lot of bootlickers who say "well if you're good, you'll earn it back fast enough" but obviously forget this is a team-based game. There is no way to earn SR back quickly when you're demoted and punished for playing the game itself. 
Then there's the matchmaking. Someone really needs to explain how I, as being demoted to Silver 5, am being placed with a team of 3/5 Diamond/Masters. Given last season's progress, I would love to think I made it there, but since the rest of the lobby is actually Silver, I'm curious as to what's going on. This critical fault fills competitive with misery and takes away the fun as, again, it is a team based game. 
Another problem with comp is the number of leavers. Blizzard can't really do anything about this aside from fix broken mechanics and make an actual game, but we know they won't. The problem was lesser in OW1 and it may have something to do with OW1 having a paywall.

General Problems.
I really can't say much here because there's an overwhelming amount to talk about. There are problems in this game that have existed for SIX YEARS without as much as a blink in their direction. When it comes to actually addressing problems, you can rest assured that Blizzard will only exacerbate the problem so they can stir up the community's participation; they feed on our hope that "maybe that one thing was finally fixed!"

If you have to purposefully break your game's dynamics to attract more players, or you had to make your game free because not even the people who bought it were playing, it might be time to quit/retire from game development. I didn't pay a dime for anything related to this game, but feel more cheated than I did by Battlefield 2042. 

If you want to have fun playing OW2, either do not play it, or stick to custom matches (amateurs can make better games than Blizz devs).

A lot of people like to criticize the game because of prior missteps, issues with monetization, or problems with the owning company.  But here's the reality: Overwatch is the best shooter in its class and offers a ton to any player looking for something a little more unique than your standard FPS fare.  The heroes are all incredibly fun to play, and there's nothing quite like zipping around the battlefield as a Tracer or asserting your dominance as a Reinhardt.  The art team does an immaculate job with the hero and map designs, making the aesthetic super pleasing to look at.  There's a ton of map variety, and with the addition of a new core game mode, tons of ways to play the game.  You can delve into the competitive ecosystem if you're looking for something more serious and want to improve your game, or head to quick play for something a bit more casual.  Looking for something a bit more goofy?  The arcade has plenty of rotating gamemodes including deathmatch, elimination, ctf, mode-specific queues, low gravity, low cooldown, mystery heroes (technically in unranked, but whatever), and regular seasonal modes as the year goes on.  There's also a custom game creator where users can script their own game modes using tools provided by the devs, and there's tons of modes that you can easily sink dozens of hours into.  Since OW2 launched, the dev team has been very consistent in communicating ~2 weeks through a blog post and ensuring that there's some new mode or challenge to work towards every 2-3 weeks, with the most recent mode being a version of prop hunt that my friends and I loved playing.  Any purchases in the game are either purely cosmetic items or speed up the unlocking of a new hero, which can be done regardless through completing relatively easy challenges.  I have over 1600 hours between my playtime in OW1 and OW2 on Battle.net, and can't wait to spend many more now that I can play it through Steam.  I'd recommend this game to anyone in a heartbeat, there's just nothing quite like it.

I played this game since 2016 with almost a 1000 hours. What made the game good was the old dev team with Jeff Kaplan. We miss you Jeff. Screw all those new dev directors and higher ups who are all after nothing else but money. 

The game is just a cash grab now. At first only skins cost money, but now also PvE missions. You have to pay 15.

With Overwatch 1 is was just a one time payment and you were set for good. There were lootboxes, but those were the most generous lootboxes in gaming history. And you got a ton of them for free by just playing. I rarely spent extra money and got pretty much all the cosmetics within the first few years. But those were the good old days. 

Anyway, aside from the dev team. This game relies way too much on teamplay, which makes the game very frustrating if you have a bad team. Worse than in other games. Especially recently.
